utterances: What was your picture called, Ericka?
All in one.
When you look at this picture, I'm going to describe it.
It is - all these different angles on a person who has all these different colors, two mouths and one part has what looks like hair, the other part doesn't.
And what does that mean to you?
Well, it expresses that no matter who we are, what we look like, we shall all still maybe get along, have each other's back, no matter what.
And it's a good thing that if that happens, it'll be a great thing.
Do you think it is happening in New Orleans?
Well, yes, even closer to happening.
Now, you see more people hanging out with each other, standing up for each other.
So, even if you have this (unintelligible), we all have each other's back or even around the world, it'll be great.
Laura, what's the most poignant moment that you had while filming the documentary?
Something that made it on camera or something that didn't make it on camera?
There were a lot of moments that were very poignant, that the kids just kind of opened up, one little girl, Destiny, when she started talking about her experience at the Superdome.

And she started drawing, and it was like this floodgate opened, and she couldn't stop talking, and drawing, and talking about this man, he was shot and then this happened, and then this happened, and this.
She was crying and it was unbelievable, like a volcano of words and drawings.
You have kids of different races in this film as well.
Was that something that you think helped tell the story of Katrina?
Yes.

We really wanted this to be a portrait of New Orleans and all the different facets of New Orleans, and that's why Ericka's drawing was so extraordinary because it really represents the film, because we did - we wanted to have kids from all different walks of life, privileged, underprivileged, and everybody in between.
And we tried to have the demographic kind of reflect the demographic of New Orleans, because it affected everybody, but obviously to very different degrees.
And that's part of the story too, the similarities and the differences.
We look at what President Bush did with the steroids in baseball, and he threw his weight around with that and actually, you know, got Congress and went on involved with baseball.

So I actually think he could do it with college football and do something with a playoff system, but I just think with the timing of them signing that new contract, I don't think it will work right now.
But if he gets elected eight years and Michelle does, maybe we possibly can.
(Soundbite of laughter)
All right.
Well, Barack Obama might be the next leader of the free world, but this is, as you say, Kevin Figgers, college football.
That will be a real test.
We'll have to wait and see.
So, moving on, fellas.
It seems like every week a sports figure says something that gets him in hot water.
Last week, Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Donavon McNabb did not know that a pro football game could end in a tie.
That's after his team tied with the Cincinnati Bengals 13-13 on Sunday.
Took a lot of flak for that, but apparently a lot of guys in the NFL don't know the overtime rule, either.
So the question, Kevin, is shouldn't the quarterback, the team leader, know better?
You would think so, especially a veteran like Donavon McNabb who's been in the league for, I believe, what, 11 years now?
Yeah.
So he should definitely know what the rules are.
And you know, the - he's been in the league a long time.
He's a veteran.
He's played against a team that - in the post-season against Michael Vick, a Falcons team that actually went into an overtime game.
So when you know that a team was 9-6-1 that you played in the post-season before, you have to know what the rules of the game are.
I realize these guys are athletes and a lot of them really don't pay a lot of attention to external things like that.
They're so focused on the game they're trying to win that they don't really recognize all of the rules.
So I can kind of see that, but in a certain way, if you're the team leader, you need to know what situations your team needs to be in in order to win or to prevent overtime or to prevent a tie.
Now, in his defense, Carron, Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Rothlesberger says he thinks about half the guys in the league also don't know the rule.
But McNabb, who's already under fire for Philly's 5-4-1 record, which is dead last in the NFC East, didn't help his popularity with such an uninformed comment, especially coming from him.
Is he headed out the door now in Philly?
I believe he is.
Ben Rothersberger took up for him, but like he said, 50 percent of the guys in the league - but 50 percent of the guys in the league aren't the face of their franchise like Donavan is.
I mean, he's the Campbell Soup man.
He's been the face of Philly, like Kevin said, for eleven years.
Donovan has to know that if you go into overtime, nobody scores, it's a tie game.
And I think with this latest thing he just put the nail in his coffin in Philly, and I don't expect him to be back next year.
I guess the bottom line, though, is should there be ties in pro football?
What do you guys say?
No, no.
I don't believe so, no. There shouldn't be ties in any sports.
Period.
No, there should be a win.
There should always be a winner.
Why do you play the game?
To win.
OK.
I'll accept that.
All right.
Exactly.
Let's move on, guys.
Quarterbacks, oh, quarterbacks.
Let's talk about Matt Ryan.
Curt Warner is on fire.
Brett Favre has the Jets believing again.
But Carron, no quarterback has perhaps turned the mood around more dramatically then Matt Ryan down there in Atlanta, where you are.
The Falcons are only 5 and 4, but folks are pretty excited about their team, aren't they?
Especially after all the stuff that happened with Michael Vick.
Yes.
Matt Ryan has the fans coming back to the Georgia Dome down here.
Everyone's a fan.
People are cheering for the Falcons, but we still haven't forgot about Michael Vick.
For us with more melanin in our skin, we still remember how the franchise did him.
And the thing is, Roddy White and Michael Jenkins are having a great years this year for the Falcons.
Roddy White will probably be a Pro Bowler, but the thing is - and our question down here is, Michael Vick threw these same passes two years ago, and you dropped them.
This year Matt Ryan, out throwing you these same balls, and you're catching them.
So why couldn't you catch these same balls for number 7?
So the folks who were supportive of Michael Vick are still supporting him.
They're not wearing his T-shirts - his numbers to the games anymore, are they?
Carron?
Not necessarily.
You're seeing more number 2 jerseys, the Matt Ryan's In the Building, but you know, it's still there.
People still miss Vick.
Matt Ryan, as good as he is - I've been a fan of the guy since Boston College.
I really want the guy to succeed, but nobody sold out the Georgia Dome like Michael Vick did.
OK.
You're OK there, aren't you?
Oh, yeah.
Something fell.
OK, that's all right.
We just want to make sure you're doing OK.
That's the ghost of Matt Ryan after you.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's talk about Kerry Collins for a moment.
He isn't getting a lot of the credit, but Kerry Collins, once he stopped bouncing around from team to team, has taken the Tennessee Titans, Kevin, all the way to the top.
As Boomer would say on ESPN, can he go all the way?
Absolutely.
He's done it before.
He's won everywhere he's gone.
He took the Carolina Panthers to the NFC Championship Game.
He went to the Super Bowl with the New York Giants.
He was having some down years in Oakland, which - who doesn't, lately?

So I mean, he goes to a situation where they run the football, they play great defense, all he's asked to do is to manage the game, but then when he's actually put in the situation where he had to win the game last week, he did that with three touchdown passes in the second half.
Those are our bloggers.
Carron Phillips blogs for the mavenreport.com.
He joined us from Georgia Public Broadcasting in Atlanta.
And Kevin Figgers blogs for am570radio.com.
He joined me right here at NPR West.
So I think Kerry Collins is a guy that you can win with.
He's very efficient.
He protects the football.
He's more mobile then people believe that he is.
So I think that you can definitely win with Kerry Collins, as long as he keeps playing the role that he's in.
We're talking about quarterbacks from another standpoint.
Carron, here's my point for you.
The guy who rang Green Bay quarterback Aaron Rodgers' bell got slapped with a $25,000 fine by Commissioner Roger Gadel.
Minnesota Viking's defensive end Jared Allen was tagged for the helmet-to-helmet hit, but this guy's always in or near this kind of on-the-field trouble, isn't he?
I mean, he got fined $50,000 for two low hits on the Texas quarterback, Matt Schaub.
Yeah, but the thing is, I'm seeing all fines lately with these hits, and it's football.
It's not powder puff.
It's not flag(ph).
It's not softball.
It's football.
And Roger Gadel, I mean, he overturned the last two that came out last week.
But I mean, they're treating the quarterbacks like fairies, like Tinkerbells.
I mean, your job is to hit the guy.
I mean, if it's a late hit, you know, throw the flag, give them a penalty, but you got to let the guys hit each other.
It's football.
It's a man's game.
Let them hit each other.
That's what Hines Ward says.
We're going to move onto that situation, too, as well, Kevin, because tonight all eyes are going to be on Pittsburgh wide out Hines Ward in a perhaps revenge game against the Cincinnati Bengals.
You may remember, Ward's blindside tackle took out Cincinnati's rookie linebacker, Keith Rivers, earlier in the season, put him out with a broken jaw.
A lot of talk about a payback.
Do you expect any of that in tonight's game?
I don't expect it.

How many times do we hear about a guy saying, oh, I have a bounty out on this guy, we're going to take this guy out, and then when the actual game starts, you really don't have time to think about that.
Anybody that's played football knows that once you get into the zone, you don't see a number or a name.
All you see is a different color jersey and a guy that you're out there trying to hit.
If you go out there with a motive of trying to zero in on one guy, that's going to mess up your entire game plan and mess up your thinking for the game.

I don't think - no matter what any of the players say, and most of them are retracting their statements now about having a bounty out on Hines Ward, those guys aren't thinking about that kind of thing.

If they want to win tonight's game, and wins have been hard to come by for Cincinnati this year, so if they want to win tonight's game, I think they'd better not worry about Hines Ward specifically and worry about the Pittsburgh Steelers as a team.
Let's talk about somebody else that has something to worry about.
Adam ""Pacman"" Jones gets another chance to literally rehabilitate himself now that the Commissioner has agreed to reinstate the troubled Dallas cornerback for - what, the umpteenth time?
But let me ask you this, both of you guys, Carron, is this different?
Should we have more sympathy because Jones' issues with the law may be because of a problem that he has with alcohol?
If you had asked me that last year, I would have agreed with you.
But I've seen Pacman outlived in Atlanta.
I've seen his antics, and like - I'm - as a blogger, as a writer, I'm tired of writing about Pacman.
I'm tired of his story, like - obviously, the guy doesn't get it, and I believe people should get second and third chances because sometimes it just doesn't click the first or second time...
Right.
But like you said, Tony, this is the umpteenth time.
Like, I think if he messes up one more time, like, I think that Dallas is going to ban him.
